questions.question: Which of the following nerves supplies the muscle that is involved in the moment given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Spinal accessory nerve Explanation: The movement shown in the image is shrugging, which is carried out by the trapezius muscles and supplied by the spinal accessory nerve. Lesion of the accessory nerve or paralysis of the trapezius leads to drooping of shoulders and difficulty in shrugging and weakness of overhead abduction. Trapezius Origin: Occipital bone and cervicothoracic spine Insertion: Scapula Bone and Clavicle Three sets of fiber: Upper: Insertion on clavicle (lateral 1/3posterior side) Middle: Insertion on acromion process anteriorly Lower: Insertion on the spine of the scapula Nerve Supply: Accessory nerve (CN XI) Action: Elevation (upper fiber) and depression (lower fiber) Retractor (Midline) Rotates the Glenoid cavity superiorly. Long thoracic nerve (Option B): Supplies serratus anterior, which is responsible for scapular

questions.question: What is the action of the muscle shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Retracts the scapula Explanation: The muscle identified in the image is the rhomboid major. Originating from the C7 and T1 vertebrae, it inserts along the medial border of the scapula. Primarily functioning as a retractor, the rhomboid major also plays roles in elevating the scapula and rotating it to depress the glenoid cavity. Muscle Muscle connecting Origin Insertion Action Nerve supply Trapezius vertebral column to scapula Spines of cervical and thoracic vertebrae lateral 1/3 I of clavicle + acromion and spine of scapula Rotation of scapula during abduction of humerus above horizontal. It is made up of 3 fibers: 1- Middle fibers: retract scapula 2- Upper fibers: elevate scapula. 3- Lower fibers: depress scapula. Accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) Rhomboid major & minor Vertebral column to scapula Thoracic spines Medial border of scapula. Retract scapula. Dorsal scapular nerve Levator scapulae Vertebral column to scapula Cervical transverse processes Medial border of scapula Elevates scapula Dorsal scapular nerve Latissimus dorsi Vertebral column to Humerus Spines of thoracic vertebrae Bicipital groove of humerus Extension, adduction & medial rotation of humerus Thoracodorsal nerve

questions.question: Match the following: Muscle Action a. Pectoralis major 1. Extension at shoulder
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1 Explanation: Correct Option: a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1 Muscle Action a. Pectoralis major 2. Flexion at shoulder b. Supraspinatus 4. Abduction at shoulder c. Infraspinatus 3. Lateral rotation of shoulder d. Latissimus dorsi 1. one-third of the clavicle Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula Lower fibers: Apex of a triangular area at the medial end of the spine of the scapula (intervening bursa) Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) and proprioceptive fibers from C3 and C4. Upper fibers: Elevate the scapula (shoulder shrugging), extend the neck (bilaterally) Middle fibers: Retract the scapula Lower fibers: Rotate the scapula upward, aiding arm abduction beyond 90 degrees Trapezius with rhomboids: Retract scapula and tilt glenoid inferiorly. Trapezius with serratus anterior: Overhead abduction and tilt glenoid superiorly. questions.question: The movements at the _______ joint permit a person to look to the right and left
questions.explanation: vertebra) and the axis (C2 vertebra) in the spine. This joint is responsible for rotational movements of the head. The axis (C2) has a peg-like structure called the dens or odontoid process, which fits into the atlas (C1), allowing for rotation. Therefore, the Atlanto-axial joint permits the specific movements required for looking to the right and left. Incorrect Options: Option A - Atlanto-occipital joint The Atlanto-occipital joint permits flexion and extension movements of the head, like nodding. It's mainly for tilting the head forward and backward, rather than side-to-side rotation. Option C - C2-C3 intervertebral joint The C2-C3 intervertebral joint permits flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation, but sideways rotation is mainly handled by the Atlanto-axial joint, not C2-C3. Option D - C3-C4 intervertebral joint The C3-C4 joint, similar to C2-C3, allows neck movements like flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation. However, it's not directly involved in sideways rotational movements.

questions.question: Retraction of the scapula is primarily done by?
questions.explanation: back and neck. It plays a key role in the movement and stabilization of the scapula. The middle and lower fibers of the trapezius muscle primarily perform scapular retraction, which involves pulling the scapula backward toward the spine. Incorrect Options: Option A - Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle protracts and rotates the scapula, stabilizing it against the rib cage. However, it doesn't directly retract the scapula at the sternoclavicular joint. Option C - Subscapularis: The subscapularis muscle, part of the rotator cuff, sits on the front of the scapula. It internally rotates the humerus and stabilizes the shoulder joint but doesn't aid in scapular retraction. Option D - Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus muscle, part of the rotator cuff, is located on the back of the scapula. It helps initiate shoulder abduction but isn't mainly responsible for scapular retraction.

questions.question: What is the cause of scapular winging?
questions.explanation: responsible for stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall. When the serratus anterior muscle is paralyzed or weakened, it can lead to winging of the scapula. This muscle is especially important for maintaining proper scapular position during movements such as pushing, pulling, and reaching. Hence, option B is correct. Incorrect Options: Option A - Trapezius: The trapezius muscle stabilizes and moves the scapula, but its paralysis typically doesn't cause scapular winging. Option C - Latissimus dorsi: The latissimus dorsi muscle assists in various shoulder movements but is typically not associated with scapular winging, even when weakened or paralyzed. Option D - Pectoralis major: The pectoralis major muscle aids shoulder movements but usually doesn't cause scapular winging if paralyzed.

questions.question: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of:-
questions.explanation: spinal stability and flexibility. Elastin fibers within it provide elasticity, enabling stretching and recoiling to maintain stability during movement. Its yellowish color comes from high elastin levels. Incorrect Options: Option A - Type 1 collagen: Type 1 collagen is abundant in tendons, ligaments, and bone, but the ligamentum flavum contains lower levels compared to other connective tissues. Option B - Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in hyaline cartilage, like in joint articular cartilage and vertebral discs, but it's not notably present in the ligamentum flavum. Option C - Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers, composed of type 3 collagen, form mesh-like networks in organs like lymph nodes and spleen, but they're not notably present in the ligamentum flavum. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine?
questions.explanation: concave shape. In the lumbar spine, lordosis is considered a normal anatomical feature. It helps to maintain the balance and proper alignment of the spine, allowing for efficient weight distribution and movement. Incorrect Options: Option A - Scoliosis: Scoliosis is an abnormal sideways curvature of the spine, typically found in the thoracic or thoracolumbar regions, not the lumbar spine. Option B - Kyphosis: Kyphosis is an excessive forward curvature of the spine, often causing a rounded or hunched-back appearance. While normal in the thoracic spine, it's uncommon in the lumbar spine. Option D - Recurvatum: Recurvatum is hyperextension of a joint, seen notably in the knee but not typically in the lumbar spine.
